segments.text: Rather, where the record has not been disturbed.
Yes, I'm sorry, where the record has not been disturbed.
Yes, that is true in a sense.
What we've been trying to do in our group is to establish phenomena as a function of time, the record of the past history.
Okay, then what are some of the things you've discovered then which have modified beliefs about, let's say, the origin of the oceans?

Well, anything that we've done that has a bearing on that subject is most closely associated with this question that lies much further back in time, the question of how matter originally formed, how solid matter originally formed in the solar system.
And those questions decide essentially where the water eventually came from that later on formed the ocean.
So in that field, it's very hard to make any really breakthroughs or major discoveries.
You work with little details in the record that is very scanty.
so limited that it's open for many different interpretations.
And what you can do is to essentially see how this record fits with the actual observations of reality today.
The field is very full of speculation.
And there are many people very interested in the question of the earliest history of the solar system.
What characterizes much of this work is that it's split up between people in different fields, chemists, physicists, geologists, who work kind of separately on these things.
And each one of them have a theory for the origin of the solar system, one for chemists, another one for physicists, a third one for geologists.
And they are rather, since there's strangely

enough little contact between them it's very rare that these different theories are confronted with each other and people find that there are where geologists thought some things were possible or likely physical laws of how matter behaves in space prohibit that and negates such a theory and what I've been interested in essentially is to
work together with, try to join information of the type that I'm particularly interested in with the information that can come from other fields.
And the collaboration that I have particularly treasured and learned much from is with the outstanding physicist professor Hannes Alv√©n.
And together we have tried to develop

some, I wouldn't even call it theories, but a framework for the permitted range of interpretations of the past history of the solar system on the basis of the boundaries of the limits that are imposed by physical and chemical laws, essentially.
That is essentially the
contribution as far as I see it in that particular field.
Exactly what is the framework around which you sketch, let's say, the origin of the universe?
That is a very interesting philosophical question.
There again, there are very different departures taken by different people through time.
One is that very commonly that you have a

brilliant idea of some kind you're fascinated by some specific phenomenon and you say wouldn't it be interesting to see if you can use that to explain a specific phenomenon to explain things in the past I think what one finds is generally that human knowledge and human human rationalization is very very limited
And if you base your approach to the history of the past on speculations without contact with reality, then you're bound.
Even if you're very smart, after a few steps, the chances that you'll go wrong is very, very high.
This is the basis of existentialism, essentially.
And I'm an existentialist.
Therefore, I think that scientists, as well as
other human beings need very badly to be guided by reality.
And the reality in this case is the situation.
If you're interested in the conditions in space in the past, then you have to ask yourself, what are the processes going on in space today?
What are the laws that govern the motion and state of matter in space today?
And there, of course, a whole new
that we didn't know very much at all 20 years ago.
All kinds of beliefs then prevailed that are completely obsolete today.

People thought that this interstellar space was a void, near vacuum, whereas now one knows it's a thin medium that is strongly electrified like northern lights, roughly, full of a network of currents and magnetic fields.
In the same way, the chemical ideas about interplanetary and interstellar space in olden days was one of such a nothingness and in between clouds of gas.
These gases were believed to be behaviors like gases in the laboratory on Earth.
That one is commonly used.
And this is where the space exploration opened up a completely new
new experimental field demonstrated how completely wrong people were.

That instead of neutral gases dominating the picture, you find that just very small degrees of ionization in these gases cause them to behave fundamentally differently from the ordinary gas dynamics laws.
And it's the laws of plasma physics and the laws of magneto-hydrodynamics that govern the behavior of matter in space.

And this is where I felt that collaboration with Professor Alv√©n was particularly informative for me, because he is one of the founders of the modern science of magnetohydrodynamics, and one of the pioneers in the understanding of how things actually behave in space,
in a way that's based on speculation, but in a way that's based on observation.
Is US spending enough money on its space program?
That is very hard to say.
I think the space program consists and has consisted of two things, science and public relations in the international arena.
And for example, the lunar program, the manned landings on the moon, were entirely, I think the justification politically for it, were not the advancement of science.
Science got a free ride there on the publicity stunt undertaken at a very grandiose scale by the United States.
to impress the world with what is possible with modern technology.
And in that program, science in the beginning was perhaps not thought of as the major purpose.
It became quite well-funded during the great era when this
played an important role in the eyes of the world.

The problem with such a background for scientific support is that when the publicity interest has dropped, people's attention span is very short, then that tends also to be a dropping interest in political support for scientific work in the field.
And this is where

at the present time, where there is needed to carry on a sustained exploration of space around us, not just for publicity, or not only for philosophical reasons, to express it in a more favorable way, but also for the understanding of nature and of the processes that ultimately have to do with everyday life on Earth.
Do you judge NASA to be too mission-oriented?
NASA has to be very mission-oriented, because the great breakthroughs that NASA has made are due to missions.
So not at all.
No, I think that is the lifeblood of modern space science, is actual expeditions into space.
They don't need to be manned, and some of the more exciting
explorations will be probably undertaken in the near future by unmanned spacecraft.

The orbiting space station around the moon, the polar orbiter that is hoped for, and parallelly, I would hope, the exploration of comets and asteroids, small bodies in the solar system, which hold the secret to the origin of the
solar system, in contrast to the planets and the moon that can't give any information about that.
Why do comments hold the secret to the solar system?
Well, I think it generally agreed on that the solar system formed from gas and dust, but perhaps hasn't dawned on everybody yet the state that this gas and dust was in and what
specific laws that follow when they form, but the general understanding is there.

And when such gas and dust clumps up together to form clumps of larger and larger size that grow and eventually form bodies as large as planets, the gravitation is so strong and the forces become so strong in these bodies that they destroy their original record.
The Earth has destroyed totally the record of the structure and composition of the original material it was made from.
It has remelted itself and is continuing to remelt its crust, at least, and spew out the remelted rocks as volcanic eruptions.
The same on any big planets, like Venus.
Mars is kind of halfway through that process.
It is more youthful, maybe, than the Earth.
all of the original material is certainly totally destroyed.
And any time you land some little chunk of original material on such a big body, just because it smashes into the surface so hard, it is destroyed.
Unless you have an atmosphere like the Earth, that makes it possible for meteorites to have soft landing.
So the bodies then that haven't grown big enough to destroy this material

The small planets, the minor planets, the so-called asteroids that cruise around mostly in orbit in space, mostly between Mars and Jupiter, and also the comets that have come from way out in the outer reaches of the solar system and come in close to the sun and go back out again.
There's quite a lot of evidence that they consist of material that has been very little altered
from its original state.
What is information science, by the way?
Information science is everything that has to do with modern computers, data, data processing.
Okay.
Well, what relationship does information science have to do with your work?
It's only a tool in all modern science, or in much of modern science.
You are aided very much by computers and by the whole science that is behind computers.
But it's not only the everyday .
It's a question of signal processing, the way you convey information in an electromechanical sense and also in the widest sense.
information by communication between people.
And what have you tried to do as associate director of the Institute for Pure and Applied Physical Sciences?
Well, that institute is essentially an outgrowth of the original Institute for the Study of Matter under Professor Mathias' direction.
By merging with some other

similarly oriented organizations, essentially this Institute for Pure and Applied Physical Sciences, originally created by Professor Keith Bruckner, one of our great physicists on this campus and our international team, joined together with the Institute for Study of Matter and formed this new structure.
And what I've been doing there is partly to

to try to draw together into that type of, the different types of research efforts that were going on in that field on this campus and to assist essentially in the effort by Professor Mathias in doing that.
Okay, and when you say draw together the different kinds of research going on on this campus, do you mean draw together the different kinds of research on this campus and apply it to space?
There is not, well,
so much in space sciences.
In this case, it's mostly in material science.
It's a material science effort that is handled by that institute.
Is it possible to, let's say, harness that enthusiasm that appeared for the original space program and turn it towards the oceans?
How do you mean, in Washington?
In Washington and with the general public.
I don't see why one should.
It's like saying you should, well, to turn the interest, the legitimate profound interest in one field of science into the equally legitimate and interesting work in another field of science.
There's no reason why one should be converted into another.
They're both justified on their own and tie in with each other.
But there's only so much of a pool, let's say, of research monies available to the academic world.
Do you feel as if, as a man who operates in both fields, may I put you on the spot here, do you feel as if we should continue with space as a major priority, or should the major priority become
oceans, or should we have no major priority?
Oh, I think we are far from the point where the amount of funds going into science, fundamental and applied science in this country, are limited by the resources of this nation.
I mean, it's just to compare the magnitudes.
The amount that went into the space program during its heydays was really costing money because of the tremendous engineering efforts.
That amount is less than people spend on smoking in the United States per year, and less than spent on cosmetics every year.
It's nothing compared to the Greengrass National Project, compared to what is spent on armament and weapons.
It's a very, very small fraction.
And that, yet, was the largest effort in science at that time.
the other branches of science, is a small fraction of that again.
So this country is devoting a very small fraction of its gross national product to the creation of new knowledge, which is essential for the future of the nation.
That leads me to another series of questions, which I'd like you to make invidious comparisons, if you don't mind.
I'm happy to make invidious comparisons.
All right.
Vis-a-vis, let's say, your original home of Scandinavia, how would you rank American scientific efforts?
Does one receive a better or a worse education in Scandinavia in terms of the sciences as a professional?
That's a very broad, it's like saying our earthlings
better or worse than Martians.

I think it's easy to speak about the education you receive or scientific training you receive in Sweden or in Norway or in Denmark because these are small, homogeneous societies which correspond in size, in geographic size, to California, for example, in Sweden.
where you have, therefore, rather unified structures in education.
In the United States, that's a continent.
You have an enormous variety of standards and of institutions ranking from completely worthless to the most outstanding in the world.
And the great institutions in this country are unparalleled anywhere in the world.
What about work and activity in, let's say, oceanography?
First, would you estimate that the United States is on par with, let's say, the oceanographic institutions of the other affluent countries in terms of science?
Let's say Germany, the Soviet Union, and the Scandinavian countries.
I would say in each of these groups,
and particularly the ones, the wealthier nations that are so large that they can afford a massive effort.
Scandinavian countries don't belong there.

Their effort in these expensive fields must necessarily be limited and spotty, limited to certain periods of time when there's a giant effort, like in the 1880s or in the 1940s during the great expeditions that were undertaken then.
In the United States and in the USSR,
Germany, France, there can be sustained efforts.
And the sustained effort in the United States is undergoing a very strong change right now.
In the USSR, it is continuing in the traditional way.
And in the USSR, everything is very structured.
The effort that has gone into
has been very extensive.
Their ships are just perfect, excellent ships.

If not designed for the purpose or selected, ships are selected for the purpose that are very expensive to roam, that serve the purpose very well, that makes it possible for people to stay at sea for very long times.
The Russian ships are roaming all the portions of the sea and people stay out for very long times.
In the United States, I would say the effort is probably much more imaginative.
But from the point of view of ships facilities, one has depended on the Navy essentially during the initial era, during the 40s and 50s and 60s.

The ships have characteristically either been local donations by some millionaire who wanted to get rid of a yacht, and in the better cases, ships placed at disposal by the U.S. Navy, but that have to be on call all the time, and therefore could not be modified for their original use, turgs, rescue vessels, things like that.
We've also, so that has marred the efficiency of the
US oceanographic fleet.
Then there's been a period during which ships, some of the ships, were designed actually for oceanographic purposes.
But my regard for most of these designers is not very high.
The results are not really
vessels that are characterized by the utmost in modern engineering and skill, but rather, I mean, some of them rather amateurishly done and become rather rapidly outdated.
Many of them have low speeds and therefore can't achieve so much at any given time.
And also I think the Puritan aspect of the American society prevents the creation
on board of comfortable quarters for the crew and for the scientific crew and for the sailors and officers, it somehow goes against the grain.
People should be comfortable on board.
As a result, in contrast, for example, on the Russian ship, people live in great luxury, but in great comfort.
That, I think, has... As a result of that, you can never keep people on board on the macro ship for a long time.
As a result, you have to fly them out to wherever to change crew all the time, every six weeks or so, and it becomes very, very costly to exchange crews.
And also, to keep morale high on board is very difficult because of the rather limited comfort and...
That is deplorable in a way.
How many oceanographic voyages have you made?
Oh, I've lost track of them.
Nowadays, I go out very rarely.
But the major expeditions lasting for some considerable time, half a dozen or so.
